Acting Sustainably for our own “Spiritual” Well-Being

Should we protect the Earth or use it for everything it has and move on?

Daniel Goldman
Mar 1

I’m a fan of sustainable practices. In the short run, I think we need to maintain a certain degree of sustainability to stop the poisoning of our own environment and thus our own bodies. However, I’ve also grappled with the question of why we shouldn't just soak this planet for everything it has and move on. After all, if there’s any fundamental purpose in life, it’s just to live.

So long as we live and our descendants live, does it matter if other things don’t? Do we really have any kind of responsibility towards the environment or towards this planet? If I were religious, I could cite various ethical reasons, such as “god is just lending us this planet.” Okay. But I don’t believe this notion.

Does any other organism worry about how its own growth and actions affect other species? Do we attack beavers for changing their environment with dams? For some reason, we hold ourselves to a standard that we hold no other species to. We are expected to reduce our own success for the benefit of other species.

And it’s not like being incredibly sustainable is going to get us all that far, if we still don’t move on from this world. Between super volcanoes, asteroids, global pandemics, and all sorts of other threats, our species could be wiped out at any time. That’s why I think we’re already behind schedule when it comes to being ready to go to Mars.

So Why?

I think that the best answer might be “it’s good for us.” It keeps us spiritually healthy. Now, I don’t mean spiritual in the religious sense, or any esoteric sense. But through sustainable living, we remain mindful of ourselves and our surroundings. It helps us from moving down the path of self destructive tendencies, of becoming a plague of locusts on the universe.

And no, I don’t think that we’ll consume like locusts, or that we’ll run out of resources. Considering how vast the universe is, good luck with growing that much. But I think we’d enjoy life better, with just a little bit more mindfulness about our own actions.

We might also learn more about the world, and the universe, if we take the time to really look and wonder about it, rather than just see it as a resource for our own consumption.
